At 06:48 27/03/2007, Ken wrote:
>Joe, I may not be fully understanding your point, so I wanted to ask
>for clarification.  My point was only that CPPNs can abstract away
>the temporal unfolding and local interaction that are usually
>associated with development.

One point worth clarifying.  The "temporal unfolding" that is 
development and the "temporal unfolding" that is learning are 
completely different processes.  _Except_ in humans where the biology 
does only a partial job of wiring the brain in the womb, and then 
spends over a decade finishing the job via experiential/experimental 
interaction with the environment.  This is a strategy for being 
generalists.  We don't have enough instinct to fully form ourselves.

There is also a known phenomenon for the transfer of learned 
behaviour into genetic programming: the Baldwin effect.  Worth 
reading up on if you haven't already encountered it.

         Ian
